This contribution presents a viable gaseous hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) route for Levoglucosan (LG) that leads to the formation of non-oxygenated hydrocarbon cuts that make commercial transportation fuels, namely gasoline, diesel, and jet fuels. The outlined process encompasses HDO of an evaporated stream of dissolved LG over 5% Ni-CeO2 catalysts between 100 °C–500 °C. It is found that the load of the aliphatic compounds attains values between 68.1% and 75.3% across the investigated temperature window. Similarly, fractions of aromatic compounds remain within 8.1%–13.9%. Major observed aliphatic compounds include tetradecane, dodecane, octane, and decane. Alkylated benzenes appear in appreciable quantities. Governing HDO's mechanisms were mapped out by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Utilizing a 10% load of Ni has slightly reduced the relative area of aliphatic compounds. The combined area of the oxygenated compounds remains less than 10% at all temperatures. This finding entails a profound HDO's capacity of the deployed catalyst and opens a direct venue for the effective utilization of LG in fuel production. Graphical abstaract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Levoglucosan Hydrodeoxygenation Catalysis Reaction pathways Fuel Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With a fraction of 40%–50% in biomass, cellulose represents the most prolific source of carbon-based renewable energy [1]. As nonedible biomass, the position of cellulose in the hierarchy of the renewable energy sector becomes even more apparent when compared with commercial oil-generating crops and starch [2]. There has now been a clear shift from the direct use of biomass as a source of energy and heating toward the production of value-added products and transportation fuels [3]. This is attained by various chemical and biotechnological methods [4,5]. For instance, direct pyrolysis of cellulose produces levoglucosan (LG) or 1,6-anhydro-β-D-glucopyranose) as a major intermediate [6]. LG constitutes an anhydrous sugar that emerges from a simple ether bond breakage in cellulose's building blocks [7]. It is a cyclic- hemiacetals that appear in the top list of biomass-derived chemical platforms introduced by the US. Department of Energy [8]. Further chemical transformation of LG affords a wide array of potentially useful products, most notably furfural, glycerol, levoglucosenone (LGO), hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), and sorbitol [9–11]. The yield of LG from cellulose pyrolysis significantly varies between 20%–60% in a flow reactor at 400 °C and displays sensitivity on the deployed operational parameters like conversion of acid-treated sugarcane bagasse into LG [12,15]. However, admitting hydrogen resulted in the complete degradation of LG into oxygenated and non-oxygenated compounds [13,14]. Some articles study the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of LG in the aqueous medium over a wide array of catalysts [16]. It was concluded that with the presence of three vicinal OH groups, regioselective deoxydehydration into selected products proves very challenging. The alkaline content in cellulose mediates decomposition reactions, thus reducing selectivity toward LG [17]. It is often viewed that the yield of LG is affected by the degree of polymerization as well as the crystallinity of cellulose. Chemically, LG forms in the first stage of cellulose decomposition via transglycosylation reactions before hydration and ring-opening reactions [18]. Through density functional theory (DFT) computations on surrogate compounds, detailed reaction mechanisms were mapped out for the formation of LG from cellulose where concerted-like and water-elimination OH migration steps generally prevail [19]. LG production from cellulose pyrolysis is maximized by optimum working temperature between 400 °C–500 °C, pre-removal of mineral content, rapid heating rate, and short residence time i.e., 1 s. Advances in pretreatment and pyrolysis technologies have increased yields. Methanol, acetaldehyde, and furans are important secondary products from LG conversion [20–21]. The need for post-neutralization treatment of the deployed reactive aqueous mixture calls for using heterogeneous catalysts where the process ensues in a non-corrosive environment. The industrial-scale operation of these aforementioned hydrolysis reactions is hindered in view of the harsh operational conditions, most notably exceedingly high temperatures and pressures. This has paved the way to investigate catalytic upgrading of LG's vapor pyrolysates .Catalytic upgrading of LG's vapor pyrolysates has been studied in the presence of HZSM-5 catalysts at 500 °C–600 °C [11]. Oxygenated compounds such as furfural, furan, and 2-methyl furan serve as precursors to synthesize non-oxygenated aromatic compounds, most notably benzene, xylene, and toluene, i.e., the BXT fraction. Fe-CeO2 catalysts have also been used to convert LG's pyrolysates into carbonyl compounds (i.e., ketones and aldehyde) with a yield of ∼30%.. Further investigation is needed to understand the effect of by-products on selectivity and deactivation of deployed catalysts [20–22]. To the best of our knowledge, literature presents no accounts of the HDO of LG in the gas phase over decorated transition metal oxides. Success in removing the oxygen content from LG in a heterogenous catalyzed process opens a venue to utilize it in the production of commercial transportation fuels. Attaining this task at the laboratory scale signifies the objective of this work. The utilized catalyst herein is 5% Ni loaded on ceria. This catalyst formulation has been very effective in HBO's applications of real samples of biomass and their model compounds [23,24]. HDO's capacity for this catalyst stems from a facile dissociative uptake of hydrogen molecules over isolated metallic Ni sites [25]. Outcomes demonstrated herein offer an alternative to the commonly applied HDO process for LG in the aqueous medium that often ensues under harsh conditions of a corrosive environment and excessive operating parameters. Similarly, experimental results, and mapped-out mechanisms illustrate relatively feasible routes for producing value-added products from the catalytic upgrading of LG, thus, reaffirming its status as a prominent chemical platform. 2 Methodology 2.1 Materials Precursors used in the preparation of the Ni-CeO2 catalysts were Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (purity ≥99.0%, Sigma Aldrich) and cerium oxide (purity ≥99.0%, Sigma Aldrich). 1,6-Anhydro-beta-D glucose (or LG) of the analytical standard was also sourced from Sigma Aldrich. 2.2 Catalyst preparation and characterization To prepare the nickel-cerium oxide catalyst, the incipient wetness impregnation method was adopted. Briefly, the preparation entails weighing suitable grams of the Ni precursor and then dissolved in de-ionized water. Afterward, the solution was added to the CeO2 precursor until a slurry was formed, resulting in 5 and 10%Ni in the catalyst's total weight. The catalyst was stirred and heated until a solid was formed with minute H2O. The solid formed was dried overnight at 105 °C in an oven and stored in an airtight container. Calcination was carried out for 4 h at 500 °C under a flow of zero air by maintaining a ramp rate of 10 °C /min. The prepared catalyst was characterized to elucidate Ni's influence on CeO2. Essentially, X-ray diffraction (XRD) by using PANalytical Instrument (X'Pert3 Powder, Philips, Holland), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) by (JOEL JSM 6010 PLUS/LA), Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) by (FEI Spirit G2 BioTwin, Tecnai (200KV), Eindhoven, Netherlands) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis (XPS) were obtained using a Kratos Axis Supra instrument, Quantachrome ChemBET-TPR/TPD chemisorption instrument was used for temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and N2 adsorption-desorption was obtained by Quantachrome Instrument (NOVAtouch NT 2LX-1, USA) were all implemented. Underlying details of the adapted methodologies and procedures can be found in our recent study [26]. 2.3 Experimental setup Fig. 1 illustrates the schematic setup of the catalytic pyrolysis reactor utilized. A quartz tube constitutes the tubular reactor where the surface-assisted HDO reaction occurs. The reactor is enclosed by an electric furnace where the temperature is digitally controlled. The furnace (SAFTherm, China) operates in the temperature range of 5 °C–1200 °C. The products were collected and analyzed in this study at temperatures 100 °C, 200 °C, 300 °C, 400 °C, and 500 °C. The choice of this particular range follows the commonly deployed temperature interval in the pyrolysis and catalytic upgrading of biomass model compounds and span lower and intermediate temperature windows [17,27]. 12.5 mg of solid LG was dissolved in 10 ml of water, which was further introduced to the reactor using a syringe pump (TYD 01). Following the syringe pump, the dissolved LG solution was heated with a heating tape maintained at 250 °C to evaporate the solution before passing into the reactor. The flow rate of dissolved LG was retained at 0.0833 ml/min along with 100 ml/min of a 5% H2 stream balanced in 95% He (the H2:LG ratio was fixed at 60:1 throughout the reaction). A catalytic bed of 10 mm thickness was prepared using quartz wool and placed perpendicular to the gas flow. The catalyst bed was placed in the heating zone of the reactor. Before the reaction, the prepared catalyst was reduced for two hours at 500 °C in a 5% H2 balanced stream in He. Due to the plausible condensation of the products leaving the heating zone of the reactor, the preceding area of the reactor after the zone was maintained at 250 °C using a heating chord connected with a PID controller. The condensable fractions were collected using an ice trap containing the impinger bottle filled with dichloromethane, whereas the non-condensable fractions were collected using a Tedlar bag before analysis. 2.4 Products analysis The condensable and non-condensable products were characterized using an FTIR (Bruker Invenio-S equipped with a gas sampling cell heated to a constant temperature of 250 °C) and a GC–MS (GC–MS 8890, Agilent Technologies, US). GCMS measurements deploy a split ratio of 10:1 and helium as a carrier gas at a flow rate of 1 ml/min. The column (HP-5MS-UI) was maintained at 250 °C and connected to the MS at 300 °C. The temperature ramped from 50 °C at a rate of 15 °C /min. The separated fragments in the GC column were detected via the MS based on their characteristic molecular ion ratio (m/z) in the scan range of 30–550 against spectra tabulated in the NIST library. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations Details of DFT methodology, convergence criteria, computational framework, and deployed structure of the NiH_CeO2(111) surface follow from our recent study on the partial hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene [26]. In summary, the CASTEP code [28] carries out all DFT calculations, computes reaction and activation energies, and optimizes all structures based on the PWA function [29]. The considered computational methodology utilizes a plane wave cutoff energy of 400 eV and a 2 × 3 × 1 κ-points sampling. “on the fly,” Pseudopotential” accounts for the electronic interaction. Convergence criteria of final energies and maximum forces were set to 0.001 eV/atom, 0.03 eV/Å, and 0.001. Transition states were located using the LST/QST method [30]. The surface was constructed by a 1 × 2 unit cell of ceria terminated along the [111] direction where the bottommost two atomic layers were fixed at their bulk positions. Elemental Nio observed in XRD/XPS measurements was modeled via a cluster of Ni atoms deposited at the surface. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, and XPS analysis Fig. S1 (Supporting Materials, SM) shows the pore diameter of the CeO2 support and 5%Ni-CeO2 catalysts. As observed, both samples reveal a narrow size distribution with a maximum pore diameter of less than 40 nm. The samples’ obtained BET surface areas (Table 1 ) show that the inclusion of Ni into the CeO2 support does not negatively influence the surface area. Fig. 2 a depicts the XRD spectra observed for the pure CeO2, the calcined, and the reduced catalysts. All the samples indicate CeO2 patterns typical of the fluorite cubic CeO2 structure (JCPDS 43–1002), as previously reported [26]. The most intense peak observed at 28.7° is ascribed to the Ce(111) surface. Doping the support with Ni preserves the crystallinity, and the peak of NiO was detected after calcination, confirming the formation of Ni on CeO2 catalysts. The reduction of the samples for 2 h at 500 °C afforded the transformation from NiO and the detection of Ni on the catalysts. For clarity purposes, the expanded spectra of the identified NiO and Ni peaks are shown in Fig. 2b. The electronic states and surface compositions of the catalysts were examined with the XPS analysis and the Ce 3d, Ni 2p, and O 1 s results are shown in Fig. 3 . The ratio of the Ce3+ to the Ce4+, Ni0 to Ni2+ and that of the adsorbed O atoms to the lattice O atoms are shown in Table 1. Overall, the Ce 3d entails ten zones, divided into six zones; the 3d5/2 (v, v11, v111) and 3d3/2 (u, u11, u111), typifying the electrons of the Ce4+ oxidation states. The other four zones are divided into 3d5/2 (v1, u1) and 3d3/2 (v0, u0), which are representative of the electrons of the Ce3+ states. Predominantly, the support and the Ni-doped sample demonstrate the coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+, with the support containing a moderate amount of Ce3+. The presented result shows that the incorporation of Ni does not influence the reduction of Ce atoms. For instance, as revealed in Table 1, the reduced CeO2 support has 51.82% of Ce3+ on the surface, while this value is 42.35% for the reduced 5Ni-CeO2. Ce3+ on the catalyst's surface will further enhance the activity toward the hydrodeoxygenation reaction [31]. The Ni 2p reveals two distinct peaks, primarily of the Ni0 (852 eV) and Ni2+ (855 eV) states. What is obvious in the samples is the existence of the Ni2+ that dominates the Ni0 states. The possibilities that could have ensued during the reduction process leading to this occurrence can be explained as follows. It could be that a few of the Ni2+ atoms were strongly bonded onto the CeO2 support, which resulted in the reduction of the moderately bonded nickel oxide to metallic nickel, Ni0. As shown in Table 1, comparing the amount of metallic Ni on the Ni oxides, only 13.78% of the Ni atoms are in the reduced form after the H2 treatment. This observation agrees with Ce 3d because; the main reduction of Ce3+ occurs within the vicinity of the reduced Ni species. Thus, any H2 within this locality of Ni0 species will undergo the spill-over effect to the neighboring Ce4+ atoms to initiate the reduction to Ce3+. It follows that a few spilling of H2 might have occurred on the Ni-doped catalyst, which does not lead to a significant reduction of CeO2 [32,33]. 3.1.2 SEM, H2-TPR analysis and TEM, HR-TEM As Fig. 4 shows, the SEM analysis examined the morphologies of the CeO2 support and the 5%Ni–CeO2. As observed, the CeO2 particles display irregular size distribution, and the irregularity is conserved after doping with Ni. The CeO2 surface does not contain obvious pore gaps or openings, thus, eliminating the possibility that Ni particles deposit mainly in the CeO2 lattice rather than on the surface [34]. This observation agrees with the H2-TPR result depicted in Fig. 5 . The H2 consumption observed on the CeO2 at 588.8 °C is ascribed to the reduction of surface oxygen, which facilitated the increase in Ce3+ composition realized in the XPS analysis. The reduction of 5%Ni–CeO2 at 540.5 °C is associated with the reduction of NiO particles to Ni metal on the CeO2 surface and reveals that strong metal support interaction exists between the Ni and CeO2 [35]. As previously reported, the reduction of NiO to Ni on different supports span the temperature window of 390–750 °C, which is contingent on the degree of the interaction of Ni with the support. H2 consumption at a rather too low temperature was ascribed to weaker binding of the Ni metals to the support, while the reduction peak at a higher temperature signifies the higher metal support interaction In the current study in Fig. 5, the reduction temperature of NiO confirms that moderate interaction exists between Ni and CeO2. This observation will enhance their participation during the Levoglucosan reaction. The Ni metal will serve as active dual sites hosting both the Levoglucosan and dissociating the H2 molecules. In a similar experiment involving only the CeO2 support, Levoglucosan breakdown was inhibited. It was inferred that the transformation of Levoglucosan was only be promoted in the presence of Ni metal. The XPS result in Table 1 revealed the presence of Ce3+ on the catalysts. The Ce3+ state accounts for the activity commonly observed on CeO2, however, we argue that, such activity is only promoted in the presence of an active metal that is potent enough to dissociate the H2. The peak observed for the pure CeO2 at 400–620 °C is that of the surface reduction. The bulk reduction of CeO2 was not observed until 800 °C signifying that higher reduction temperature is required to initiate the bulk reduction of CeO2. In addition, the 5%Ni-CeO2 shows only one peak. However, this peak belongs to the reduction of NiO to Ni, and overlaps with the surface reduction of CeO2. This conclusion is objective because, the intensity of H2 consumption does not correspond with the amount of Ni metal on the surface determined from XPS (13.78%). Thus, the peak shown for the 5%Ni-CeO2 belongs to both the surface reduction of CeO2 and the reduction of NiO to Ni metal. Fig. 6 shows the morphology of reduced and spent catalysts and also the size of the supported Ni particles obtained with the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). The Ni particles for the reduced Ni-CeO2 catalyst are smaller, with the statistically average Ni particle size of about 28 nm. However, Fig. 7 a represents the highest number of reduced Ni particles in the range of 20–30 nm, and there are particles between 20–25 nm and another between 35–40 nm. On the other hand, the average size of Ni particles for the spent catalyst is about 29.13 nm, and Fig. 7b shows that the particle size range for the spent catalyst span 0 nm to 60 nm, which is larger than the reduced catalyst. The increase in the particle size after the reaction shows the presence of Ni agglomeration on the catalysts. Additionally, HRTEM results show that the exposed plane of CeO2 support is mainly (111) with an interplanar spacing of 0.29 nm, in agreement with the XRD results. 3.2 Formation of fuel fractions Condensable products were determined via pyrolysis of LG over a temperature range from 100 to 500 °C where the relative areas (%) were noted. Tables S1-S5 in Supplementary Materials (SM) enlist relative areas of all compounds. Fig. 8 represents the distribution for relative areas of the aliphatic and aromatic compounds at these temperatures. No unreacted LG could be detected in the GCMS spectra at all temperatures. The relative load of aliphatic compounds significantly overshoots the corresponding value of aromatics. It is observed that the areas of aromatic and aliphatic compounds vary slightly over the temperature range. For instance, the load of the aliphatic compounds remains within 68.1%–75.3% across the temperature window of 100 °C–500 °C. Similarly, the fraction of aromatic compounds attains values between 8.1%–13.9% in the same temperature range. The combined percentage area of the oxygenated compounds remains less than 10%. This finding indicates that the deployed Ni–CeO2 displays a profound HDO capacity toward LG. Oxygen-free molecules stem from removing OH groups followed by molecular arrangements, as discussed in Section 3.4. Benzene derivatives such as 1,3-bis(1,1-dimethylethyl)-benzene (6.0%) and 1,3- dimethyl-Benzene (1.1%) appear in appreciable quantitates. It is generally viewed that cerium (Ce) displays a significant impact on suppressing the production of coke and improving the thermal stability of the catalyst, whereas nickel displays a positive effect on considerably upgrading oxygenates into hydrocarbons. Next, we turn our attention to assess the effect of added load of Ni on the relative distribution of products. This is attained by comparing obtained products in the condensed fraction at 5% and 10% Ni. The main condensable pyrolytic products were found at 400 °C utilizing a loading of 10% Ni-CeO2 catalyst. The condensable fraction mainly constituted benzene derivative products, such as toluene (8.19%), Styrene (2.73%) and 1,3-bis(1,1-dimethylethyl)-Benzene (2.5%). Additionally, the relative load of octane resides at 10.53%. Decane derivatives constituted decane at 11.48%, dodecane at 9.95%, tetradecane at 9.2% and hexadecane at 4.59%, were the latter can be utilized as diesel fuel. Other secondary products found in the condensable fraction were 4-methyl-Heptane, 2,7,10-trimethyl-dodecane, 4-methyl-Tridecane and 2,4-dimethyl-Benzo[h]quinolone. Via comparing the condensable products at 400 °C from utilizing different Ni-CeO2 loadings at 5% and 10% in Fig. 9 , it can be observed that the relative area of the aliphatic compounds has slightly reduced, as the loading increased. On the other hand, the relative areas of the aromatic compounds have increased, and no oxygenated Aliphatic compounds were observed at 10% Ni-CeO2. Additionally, the relative area of the oxygenated aromatics remains unchanged. Overall, it is concluded that increasing the loading leads to a better selectivity of products. For the non-condensable analysis between 100 °C–500 °C, most of the products identified were undesirable, i.e., non-fuel compounds. For example, 2,4-dimethyl-Benzo[h]quinolone is a major product in the gas fraction from 200 °C to 500 °C. 2,4-dimethyl-Benzo[h]quinolone is directly sourced from the fragmentation of biomass [36]. The peak area of 2,4-dimethyl-Benzo[h]quinolone at a temperature of 200 °C stands at 18.8%. At a temperature of 300 °C, the peak area of the compound increases to 58.6%. The area of the product gradually decreases to 42.6% .and 24.9% at temperatures 400 °C and 500 °C, respectively. In addition, 2-ethylacridine compound was present at a temperature of 500 °C with a peak area of 31.6%. 2-ethylacridine originates from the degradation of the N-content of the biomass [37]. Fig. 10 portrays the variation in the relative loads of main aliphatic (tetradecane, dodecane, octane, and decane) compounds with temperatures. In the range of 100 °C–200 °C, the aliphatic compounds with the highest relative areas encompass tetradecane (14.5%), dodecane (13.4%), octane (12.2%), and decane (10.9%). As Fig. 10 shows, loads of these compounds display slight changes with temperatures. For instance, the area of the decane decreased from 13.7% (100 °C) to 9.8% (400 °C). Dodecane and tetradecane incur the highest relative areas at all the temperatures that enhance from 13.41%–14.5% to 17.5%–17.62% when the temperature increases from 100 °C to 400 °C. Detected decane derivatives include octadecane and hexadecane of the same relative area (7.9%), between 100 °C–200 °C. At the temperature of 200 °C, more derivatives for the aliphatic compounds appear, such as 3,3-dimethyl-octane, 4,6-dimethyl-undecane, 7-methyl-1-undecane, 2,6,10- trimethyl-dodecane, hexadecane, and octadecane. Moreover, cyclic compounds like 1,2- dibutyl-cyclopentane and 1,1,13,5-tetramethyl-,trans-cyclohexane were present across all investigated temperatures. Derivatives of the aliphatic compounds decrease as the temperature increases. Other aliphatic compounds like 4-methyl-heptane, 2,3,4-trimethyl-pentane, 6,6-diethyl hexadecane and 1 2,4-dimethyl-1-heptene appear in low areas. Fig. 11 shows the relative total areas of various components in the different categories of automotive gasoline, jet fuels, alkylated benzenes, and diesel fuel, ranging from 100 °C to 500 °C. Jensen et al. [38] presented the percentage of hydrocarbons in the different fractions of automotive gasoline (hydrocarbon from C5 to C9), jet fuel (hydrocarbon from C9 to C15), and diesel fuel (hydrocarbon from C15 to C21) calculated according to their respective ranges of fuels. The highest percentage is pertinent to jet fuel in the range of 47.0%–68.0% between 100 °C to 500 °C. Fractions of gasoline appear in the range of ∼ 9.0%–22.9%. 3.3 FTIR analysis Fig. 12 . depicts FTIR peaks for gaseous products. A detailed analysis of TGA products coupled to FTIR was reported by Li et al. [15]. LG is easily volatilized, and small amounts of formaldehyde, CO, CO2, water, and some carbonyl compounds were formed even at room temperature of 25 °C. However, at higher temperatures, formaldehyde, methane, and acetaldehyde appear to be major products from the decomposition of LG at spectral regions of 3200–2700 cm−1. Employing a Ni–CeO2 catalyst for LG's HDO affords the removal of formaldehyde at higher temperatures with the corresponding formation of the more valuable aliphatic and aromatic compounds. FTIR spectra confirmed the presence of peaks at 3200–2700 cm−1, which were earlier ascribed to formaldehyde, methane, and acetaldehyde emission. Nonetheless, over the Ni–CeO2 catalyst, GCMS analysis indicates the complete absence of these products. These peaks shown at the region 3200–2700 cm−1 are ascribed to forming other alkane products such as octane, decane, 4-methyl-Heptane, and tetradecane. GCMS product analysis indicates the formation of these compounds (Section 3.2). The peaks in the range of 2400–2000 cm−1 signify the formation of CO2 and CO [49]. The peak at 2055.3 cm−1 represents CO formation due to the cracking of aldehydes. In addition, this range also contains the O=C=O stretching group, which belongs to CO2. On the other hand, the decomposition of the carboxylic acid compounds (2-decyl pentadecyl ester-fumaric acid and 2-octyl undecyl ester-Fumaric acid) - formed during the pyrolysis of LG - leads to the formation of CO and CO2. Moreover, the strong absorption bands appearing at 1720–1706 cm−1 represent the vibration of the O-H bond, corresponding aliphatics, and aromatics containing alcohol groups and carboxylic acids [39]. During the pyrolysis reaction, the formed ester components, such as Isodecyl methacrylate, lead to the appearance of carboxylic acids due to the decomposition of the esters groups at higher temperatures. In FTIR analysis, some peaks are observable in the 1238–1295 cm−1. This range features O-N stretching group, which belongs to amine compounds, most notably1-octadecanamine and 3,3′-Iminobispropylamine, confirmed from the GCMS analysis. Other peaks in the range of 870–982 cm−1 show another C=C bending for a trisubstituted compound (2,6,10-trimethyl- dodecane) and a C–H bending for a 1,3- disubstituted compound (1,3-bis(1,1-dimethylethyl)-Benzene). The benzene derivatives such as ethylbenzene and 1,3-dimethyl-Benzene are observed in the range of 651–804 cm−1 [40]. 3.4 Underlying mechanisms This section convey steps that govern the observed HDO activity of the Ni–CeO2 catalysts. As both water vapor and hydrogen molecules were co-introduced with the dissolved LG, hydrogen may stem from both molecules. Fig. 13 shows optimized geometries for NiH_CeO2(111) and NiHOH_CeO2(111) surfaces along with the LG molecule. In the NiH_CeO2(111) surface, the ceria surface is decorated with a four-atom cluster of Ni atoms, each attached to a hydrogen atom. A hydroxyl group is attached to a Ni atom in the NiHOH_CeO2(111) structure. The optimized structure of NiH_CeO2(111) reflects XRD and XPS measurements that indicate the presence of Nio species on the reduced ceria surface. As Fig. 14 depicts, hydrogen, and water molecules dissociate over the Ni° cluster through activation energies of 228.8 kJ/mol, and 206.0 kJ/mol through the transition states TSM1 and TSM2, respectively. Water splitting is noticeably exothermic at 133.2 kJ/mol. It is envisaged that both H and OH co-exist at the Ni° cluster. Representative steps in the HDO mechanism of LG are displayed in Figs. 15 and 16 . As shown in Fig. 15a for the NiH_CeO2(111) surface, the elimination of an OH group from the LG molecule is attained through an activation barrier of ∼ 90 kJ/mol through the transition state TS1. This reaction characterizes hydrogen atom transfer from the surface toward an OH group forming a water molecule. In an ensuing step, H migration to an ether O eliminates a water molecule through a two step-mechanism, S3→ S4 → S5. Associated transition states incur comparable activation energies of 140.0 kJ/mol and 158 kJ/mol. The opening H transfer from an OH site toward an OH group in the LG molecule over the NiHOH_CeO2(111) surface (Fig. 15b) entails a modest activation barrier of 93.2 kJ/mol. As Fig. 16 illustrates, H transfer/water elimination steps remove the oxygen content in the LG molecule, thereby achieving a complete HDO. The formation of heavier hydrocarbons and fractions of transportation fuels stems from further isomerization and combinations of the non-oxygenated hydrocarbons cutes. Inspections of energies in Figs 15 and 16 reveal that hydrogen transfer to the ether bridge in the carbon skeleton and subsequent water ejection are the likely rate-limiting steps. Mapped-out reactions in Fig. 16 provide a mechanistic insight into the formation mechanism that underlines the detected products in the GCMS analysis (Tables S1-S5). While the selected catalyst has already been used for real complex biomass that includes LG and other compounds [41], governing HDO's pathways, coupled with products analysis (considering only LG), explains the process's mechanism in detail. 4 Conclusions 5% Ni–CeO2 catalysts were synthesized and characterized to investigate HDO's reaction of LG within the temperature window 100 °C–500 °C. Dissolved feed of LG was introduced to the flow reactor as an evaporative stream. A wide range of unoxygenated hydrocarbon cuts was detected. The highest percentage of compounds constitute fractions germane to jet fuel within 47.0%–68.0%. Similarly, the total area of gasoline components resides in the range of ∼ 9.0%–22.9%. FTIR analysis illustrated the nature of the functional groups in the gaseous compounds. Constructed reaction pathways of the HDO's process by DFT calculations feature H transfer from NiH or NiOH sites into the hydroxyl's or ether's oxygen atoms in the LG adduct and its intermediates. Computed activation barriers for the H transfer steps incur accessible values between 80–160 kJ/mol. It is envisaged that future research directions could focus on revealing the effect of the Ni load in the catalysts or utilizing bimetallic compounds (such as Ni/Co or Ni/Pd) to achieve a 100% HDO capacity. coredata.dc:description: This contribution presents a viable gaseous hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) route for Levoglucosan (LG) that leads to the formation of non-oxygenated hydrocarbon cuts that make commercial transportation fuels, namely gasoline, diesel, and jet fuels. The outlined process encompasses HDO of an evaporated stream of dissolved LG over 5% Ni-CeO2 catalysts between 100 °C–500 °C. It is found that the load of the aliphatic compounds attains values between 68.1% and 75.3% across the investigated temperature window. Similarly, fractions of aromatic compounds remain within 8.1%–13.9%. Major observed aliphatic compounds include tetradecane, dodecane, octane, and decane. Alkylated benzenes appear in appreciable quantities. Governing HDO's mechanisms were mapped out by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Utilizing a 10% load of Ni has slightly reduced the relative area of aliphatic compounds. The combined area of the oxygenated compounds remains less than 10% at all temperatures. This finding entails a profound HDO's capacity of the deployed catalyst and opens a direct venue for the effective utilization of LG in fuel production.
coredata.dc:title: Transformation of levoglucosan into liquid fuel via catalytic upgrading over Ni-CeO2 catalysts
